text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
I'm sharing with you another street food from

Thailand this is something that you can find at 
open-air markets but you also find it also just

added to your noodle soup as a garnish will not a 
garnish an accompaniment I should say I'm talking

about fried wonton so fried wontons are just so 
addictive and delicious and really quite easy to

make it's just a little time-consuming cuz of 
all the wrapping but that's when you get your

friends and family involved alright let's get 
started so I'm gonna start by making a classic

herb paste that goes into so many Thai dishes 
and that is some garlic white peppercorns and

I'm using quite a bit here because that's where 
my heat my pepperiness is gonna come from you

can use less if you want and some cilantro 
stems usually we would use cilantro roots in

Thai cuisine but it's hard to find so the stems 
will work just fine and this combination is what

we lovingly call saam gler which means 
three friends so grind that into a paste

there we go now that all the three friends are 
very intimate with each other ie completely

smashed into a paste I'm gonna move this out 
of here into my mixing bowl just so you can see

better but if you have a big enough mortar you 
can finish the whole filling in here it's very

convenient and I am going to add it directly 
into my pork and I'm just using ground pork

here you can do ground chicken but ground pork is 
sort of the classic protein that we use for fried

wonton some people do a combination of pork and 
shrimp but bean Street snacks most of the time

the ones you find it gonna be poor cause shrimp 
is expensive everything else is really simple

just seasoning like soy sauce oyster sauce and 
I'm gonna add a touch of toasted sesame oil it's

optional but it adds a nice aroma and a touch of 
sweetness with some sugar it just helps to balance

all the saltiness you don't want too much sugar 
it doesn't you don't want it to be sweet because

the dipping sauce will be sweet now this part is 
important I'm gonna add some cornstarch and the

cornstarch will help absorb the moisture from the 
meat and everything and it's very important you

don't want this mixture to be too wet because when 
we go to fry it if you have a very moist filling

once you fry it that the part of the wonton 
wrapper that's touching the fillings gonna get

soggy really quickly so this recipe I don't add 
any eggs in the filling because that's gonna make

it too moist in your in my wonton soup recipe 
I add an egg in the filling because it keeps a

feeling nice and soft and tender but that's not 
what you want to do if you're going to fry the

wontons now you just mix it up really well and I'm 
just gonna add some chopped green onions for some

freshness stir that in and I like to stir that in 
last so you don't end up just completely smashing

it into a mush and that is it your filling is 
done and now the hard part the wrapping it's not

very hard but it's kind of annoying welcome to the 
wonton wrapping party all right ideally you would

have multiple people to help you do this so I have 
a video five different ways to wrap wontons I will

link to that up here and in the description below 
and you can use any of those methods you can just

do a simple triangle too to keep it nice and easy 
I'm gonna do what I call the sailor hat because I

think it makes a cute shape when fried so small 
amount filling and if you've not made one tongs

before you're gonna look like what that's it 
that's all you're gonna put in there trust

me it's enough okay and then you want to wet 
the edges wrap this up press out as much air

as you can and I like thinner wonton wrappers 
so when you're looking for wonton wrappers at

the store a thinner ones and also yellow ones so 
there are like dumpling wrappers that are white

and then I'm gonna wet the edge and fold it over 
and seal them this way that's it how cute is that

okay so I've got my oil heated here I actually 
want it a little lower than what I normally fry

things that so I'm looking at 325 just because 
these rappers are so delicate and they cook very

quickly and you want to give the pork time to cook 
and then keep the heat relatively low and a deep

frying thermometer like this comes in very very 
handy and they should only take one minute to two

minutes only as soon as the wrapper looks done the 
filling should also be done and they like to flip

onto one side so just you know keep turning them 
around if you notice that okay the other side's

not getting any love and you can tell that the 
wontons are crispy also when the bubbling stops

and then these are my lazy ones mmm look at these 
a plate of deep fried crispy goodness what could

be better than that right okay and I just want 
to point out the difference between one that is

wrapped well and one that is not had enough air 
pressed out of it so if you don't have too much

air inside this is what you get right like a big 
balloon like that so you want to try to press out

as much air as possible before you seal it that 
way when you wrap it it ends up like that okay

but not a big deal if it happens to you once you 
wrap too many of them you just kind of like want

to get it all over with and then after a while you 
start becoming less perfectionistic about it okay

so in terms of dipping sauce you can definitely 
just use a sweet chili dipping sauces you can buy

for this I have a recipe for homemade version 
that's really easy that you can make but what

I'm gonna do is I'm actually do a mixture of the 
sweet chili dipping sauce so this is the one that

I made okay and I'm gonna do half half with a Thai 
style sriracha so Thai style sriracha is similar

to like the ruse of Rann sriracha that you're used 
to except it's a little milder in terms of vinegar

enos it's not as vinegary it's not as spicy you 
can totally mix it with Staubach sriracha it'll

be fine I just find this combination is not a 
sweet it's spicy or it's Tangier it just goes

better with the wontons and if you want to home 
make your own Thai style sriracha I have a recipe

for that too so now it's like a sweet spicy tart 
dipping sauce put it on this guy right here oh
good

takes me right back home that is the epitome of 
crunchy deep-fried goodness it's like I can't

describe to you super crunchy as you probably 
heard and then the pork is like it's meaty it's

rich it's mommy and that dipping sauce spicy at 
Tang it all just works together so well this is

dangerously dangerously good it's a good thing 
it takes a while to put together so you can't

make too many of them so the recipe as always 
will be on hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make

it send me a photo on Facebook Twitter or 
Instagram and if you haven't subscribed to

the show make sure you do so you don't miss a 
recipe like this and click the little bell icon

as well so you get a notification when I post a 
new video and if you love the show and you want

to support us check out our patreon link in the 
description box below and I will see you next

time for your next delicious pie just fold it 
so that it so you bend it so you like oh so you

fold it inwards yeah what do you think this is 
Adam's first you go world lights of torn book
